g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Flyweight (=cache) Share objects by separating extrinsic and ...
g.text: Flyweight (=cache)Share objects by separating extrinsic and intrinsic object state to reduce memory usage.

g.title: Rectangle.119
g.desc: A ‘huge’ number of objects don’t fit in the ‘scarce’ RAM
g.text: A ‘huge’ number of objects don’t fit in the ‘scarce’ RAM

g.title: Folded Corner.138
g.desc: The Flyweight design pattern enables sharing resources to opt...

g.text: The Flyweight design pattern enables sharing resources to optimize RAM usage by seperating extrinsic object state from intrinsic object state. Extrinsic object state is context dependent, more unique and varies more often. Intrinsic object state is context independent, less unique and almost does not vary. In the Flyweight design pattern, intrinsic objects are called Flyweights and extrinsic objects are called Contexts. An example of the Flyweight pattern, from the GOF, is the Document Editor. Assume each letter in the document editor is an object that has a position and a character attribute. The character of the letter object is intrinsic, it is not context dependent, it can only be one of the 26 letters in the alphabet. However, the position of the letter object is context dependent (=extrinsic). The letter object can locate itself all across the document.The Flyweight design pattern prescribes to extract the position into a Context object and share the Letters (=Flyweights) amongst them. The Context passes the position, as a function argument, to the Letter object. This extremely simplified example does not consider all the constraints described in ‘Why?’. However, the essence is true and the approach can be used to optimize RAM consumption.

g.title: Folded Corner.196
g.desc: The Flyweight design pattern splits object extrinsic and obje...

g.text: The Flyweight design pattern splits object extrinsic and object intrinsic state to optimize RAM usage. The separation of a class, into two strongly cohesive parts, entails the negative side of the Single Responsibility principle. The separation will make the code more scattered, which negatively affects readability. Additionally, the maintainability might increase, because a developer may need to assemble and reference extrinsic and extrinsic state correctly.

g.title: Folded Corner.202
g.desc: The goal of the Flyweight design pattern is to optimize RAM u...

g.text: The goal of the Flyweight design pattern is to optimize RAM usage. However, this might be at the expense of execution speed. Execution speed can degrade in case the extrinsic state is computed and Flyweights are being looked-up. In contrast, situating extrinsic and intrinsic state within the same class might not result in this ‘overhead’, because extrinsic and intrinsic combination are almost statically defined (less computation). On the other hand, the Flyweight design pattern reduces the amount of allocation ‘calls’. This might increase the performance in contrast to creating each object from ‘scratch’. As can be conducted from above statements, the run-time cost is strongly dependent on the implementation details.

g.title: Folded Corner.205
g.desc: The Flyweight design pattern does not necessarily comply to a...

g.text: The Flyweight design pattern does not necessarily comply to a SOLID principle. The ‘gain’ of the principle lies in memory optimization, which is useful in applications where ‘massive’ amount of objects are created and RAM becomes ‘scarce’ (e.g. a gaming engine for a particle simulation). The pattern realizes memory optimization by splitting a class into two classes: one context independent (=Flyweight) and one context dependent (=Context). The context independent objects are shared among context dependent objects. In contrast, not splitting intrinsic and extrinsic state might result in duplication of context independent state, resulting in more RAM consumption. The effectiveness of the Flyweight design pattern is dependent on several factors:1. The re-use frequency of the same Flyweight across different contexts. I.e. a Flyweight is shared across at least two or more Contexts.2. The object size of a Flyweight should ‘outweigh’ the size of a reference or pointer. E.g. in C++ a reference or pointer, on 32 bit architecture, is 4 bytes. This means the Flyweight object should exceed the size of a pointer or reference to reduce memory consumption.3. Extrinsic state being computed on the ‘fly’ and not stored in a separate Context object. I.e. the system can compute the extrinsic state based on other, already existing objects.4. The overall memory optimization in contrast to the total available RAM. I.e. the RAM gain should outweigh the complexity that the pattern brings.
